t: Luke 14
Jesus at a Pharisee’s House
One*p Sabbath, when Jesus went to eat in the house of a prominent Pharisee, he was being carefully watched.
There in front of him was a man suffering from abnormal swelling of his body.
Jesus asked the Pharisees and experts in the law, “Is*r it*r lawful*r to*r heal*r on*r the*r Sabbath*r or*r not?”*r
But they remained silent. So taking hold of the man, he healed him and sent him on his way.
Then*p he asked them, “If*r one*r of*r you*r has*r a*r child*r or*r an*r ox*r that*r falls*r into*r a*r well*r on*r the*r Sabbath*r day,*r will*r you*r not*r immediately*r pull*r it*r out?”*r
And they had nothing to say.
When*p he noticed how the guests picked the places of honor at the table, he told them this parable:
“When*r someone*r invites*r you*r to*r a*r wedding*r feast,*r do*r not*r take*r the*r place*r of*r honor,*r for*r a*r person*r more*r distinguished*r than*r you*r may*r have*r been*r invited.*r

If*r so,*r the*r host*r who*r invited*r both*r of*r you*r will*r come*r and*r say*r to*r you,*r ‘Give*r this*r person*r your*r seat.’*r Then,*r humiliated,*r you*r will*r have*r to*r take*r the*r least*r important*r place.*r

But*r when*r you*r are*r invited,*r take*r the*r lowest*r place,*r so*r that*r when*r your*r host*r comes,*r he*r will*r say*r to*r you,*r ‘Friend,*r move*r up*r to*r a*r better*r place.’*r Then*r you*r will*r be*r honored*r in*r the*r presence*r of*r all*r the*r other*r guests.*r
For*r all*r those*r who*r exalt*r themselves*r will*r be*r humbled,*r and*r those*r who*r humble*r themselves*r will*r be*r exalted.”*r

Then*p Jesus said to his host, “When*r you*r give*r a*r luncheon*r or*r dinner,*r do*r not*r invite*r your*r friends,*r your*r brothers*r or*r sisters,*r your*r relatives,*r or*r your*r rich*r neighbors;*r if*r you*r do,*r they*r may*r invite*r you*r back*r and*r so*r you*r will*r be*r repaid.*r
But*r when*r you*r give*r a*r banquet,*r invite*r the*r poor,*r the*r crippled,*r the*r lame,*r the*r blind,*r
and*r you*r will*r be*r blessed.*r Although*r they*r cannot*r repay*r you,*r you*r will*r be*r repaid*r at*r the*r resurrection*r of*r the*r righteous.”*r
The Parable of the Great Banquet
When*p one of those at the table with him heard this, he said to Jesus, “Blessed is the one who will eat at the feast in the kingdom of God.”
Jesus*p replied: “A*r certain*r man*r was*r preparing*r a*r great*r banquet*r and*r invited*r many*r guests.*r
At*r the*r time*r of*r the*r banquet*r he*r sent*r his*r servant*r to*r tell*r those*r who*r had*r been*r invited,*r ‘Come,*r for*r everything*r is*r now*r ready.’*r
“But*rp they*r all*r alike*r began*r to*r make*r excuses.*r The*r first*r said,*r ‘I*r have*r just*r bought*r a*r field,*r and*r I*r must*r go*r and*r see*r it.*r Please*r excuse*r me.’*r
“Another*rp said,*r ‘I*r have*r just*r bought*r five*r yoke*r of*r oxen,*r and*r I’m*r on*r my*r way*r to*r try*r them*r out.*r Please*r excuse*r me.’*r
“Still*rp another*r said,*r ‘I*r just*r got*r married,*r so*r I*r can’t*r come.’*r

“The*rp servant*r came*r back*r and*r reported*r this*r to*r his*r master.*r Then*r the*r owner*r of*r the*r house*r became*r angry*r and*r ordered*r his*r servant,*r ‘Go*r out*r quickly*r into*r the*r streets*r and*r alleys*r of*r the*r town*r and*r bring*r in*r the*r poor,*r the*r crippled,*r the*r blind*r and*r the*r lame.’*r
“ ‘Sir,’*rp the*r servant*r said,*r ‘what*r you*r ordered*r has*r been*r done,*r but*r there*r is*r still*r room.’*r
“Then*rp the*r master*r told*r his*r servant,*r ‘Go*r out*r to*r the*r roads*r and*r country*r lanes*r and*r compel*r them*r to*r come*r in,*r so*r that*r my*r house*r will*r be*r full.*r
I*r tell*r you,*r not*r one*r of*r those*r who*r were*r invited*r will*r get*r a*r taste*r of*r my*r banquet.’ ”*r
The Cost of Being a Disciple
Large*p crowds were traveling with Jesus, and turning to them he said:

“If*r anyone*r comes*r to*r me*r and*r does*r not*r hate*r father*r and*r mother,*r wife*r and*r children,*r brothers*r and*r sisters—yes,*r even*r their*r own*r life—such*r a*r person*r cannot*r be*r my*r disciple.*r
And*r whoever*r does*r not*r carry*r their*r cross*r and*r follow*r me*r cannot*r be*r my*r disciple.*r
“Suppose*rp one*r of*r you*r wants*r to*r build*r a*r tower.*r Won’t*r you*r first*r sit*r down*r and*r estimate*r the*r cost*r to*r see*r if*r you*r have*r enough*r money*r to*r complete*r it?*r
For*r if*r you*r lay*r the*r foundation*r and*r are*r not*r able*r to*r finish*r it,*r everyone*r who*r sees*r it*r will*r ridicule*r you,*r
saying,*r ‘This*r person*r began*r to*r build*r and*r wasn’t*r able*r to*r finish.’*r

“Or*rp suppose*r a*r king*r is*r about*r to*r go*r to*r war*r against*r another*r king.*r Won’t*r he*r first*r sit*r down*r and*r consider*r whether*r he*r is*r able*r with*r ten*r thousand*r men*r to*r oppose*r the*r one*r coming*r against*r him*r with*r twenty*r thousand?*r
If*r he*r is*r not*r able,*r he*r will*r send*r a*r delegation*r while*r the*r other*r is*r still*r a*r long*r way*r off*r and*r will*r ask*r for*r terms*r of*r peace.*r
In*r the*r same*r way,*r those*r of*r you*r who*r do*r not*r give*r up*r everything*r you*r have*r cannot*r be*r my*r disciples.*r
“Salt*rp is*r good,*r but*r if*r it*r loses*r its*r saltiness,*r how*r can*r it*r be*r made*r salty*r again?*r
It*r is*r fit*r neither*r for*r the*r soil*r nor*r for*r the*r manure*r pile;*r it*r is*r thrown*r out.*r “Whoever*rp has*r ears*r to*r hear,*r let*r them*r hear.”*r
